thread.title: Treasury Volatility Falls to Two-Month Low as Greece, China Fade
thread.title_full: Treasury Volatility Falls to Two-Month Low as Greece, China Fade - Bloomberg Business

author: Wes Goodman
title: Treasury Volatility Falls to Two-Month Low as Greece, China Fade
text:
Treasury market volatility tumbled to the lowest level in more than two months as turmoil from Greece to China eased.
The Bank of America Merrill Lynch MOVE Index, which tracks price changes based on options trading, fell to 79 basis points on Wednesday, the lowest level since May 1. It slid below 2015’s average of 85 this week. A surge in volatility last year prompted U.S. officials to consider making companies that use automated trading register with the government, a report released on July 13 showed.
The biggest issues driving the Treasury market during the past month are being resolved. Greece agreed a bailout package this week, while a monthlong selloff in the Shanghai Composite Index is easing. Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen reiterated Wednesday the central bank will probably raise its main interest rate this year, while subsequent increases will be gradual.
“The biggest concerns now seem to be settling down,” said
Tomohisa Fujiki, head of interest-rate strategy for Japan at BNP Paribas SA in Tokyo. “Treasuries could be staying relatively within a small range,” he said. The company’s U.S. unit is one of the 22 primary dealers that underwrite the U.S. debt.
The benchmark 10-year note yield rose two basis points to 2.38 percent as of 11:57 a.m. Tokyo time, according to Bloomberg Bond Trader data. The price of the 2.125 percent security due in May 2025 fell 6/32, or $1.88 per $1,000 face amount, to 97 26/32.
Volatility Surge The MOVE Index surged on Oct. 15 to the highest level in a year, triggering the U.S. investigation. Ten-year yields plunged as much as 34 basis points that day, the biggest intraday decline since 2009, data compiled by Bloomberg show.
The volatility was enough to spur the Treasury Department, Fed, Securities and Exchange Commission and Commodity Futures Trading Commission to investigate.
The agencies issued a 76-page joint report , saying many traders were concerned about a lack of liquidity , and some of them disengaged their automated price-quoting systems and used manual or voice trading instead to reduce risk.
In addition to the study of whether to register companies that use automated trading, the report also said officials plan to review whether companies should be required to submit reports on their trading activity.
